figure_1.title: Fig. 1.
figure_1.caption: Breast cancer incidence rate in the period between 1995 and 2017 among: a women aged 30–90 years, b women aged 30–55 years, and c women aged 55–90 years

claims.sentence: We observed a 93% increase in overall age-adjusted breast cancer incidence through the period from 1995 to 2017 (incidence rate ratio 1.93, 95% CI 1.42–2.62) (Fig. 1).

Linear regression model
Covariates: Age at study entry
CI confidence interval, MHT menopausal hormone therapy, n number of cases, SE standard error
aUnfavorable lifestyle factors: overweight, physical inactivity, alcohol use, smoking, and hypertension
bp value reflecting difference between no unfavorable lifestyle factors and three to five unfavorable lifestyle factors
Pre-diagnostic lifestyle factors: overall mortality and breast cancer-specific mortality
Among all breast cancer cases combined, we observed a 96% increased overall mortality risk for those breast cancer cases with three to five unfavorable lifestyle factors versus no unfavorable lifestyle factors (HR 1.96, 95% CI 1.01–3.80) (Table 4, Fig. 2).

Age-adjusted hazards ratios between lifestyle and overall and breast cancer mortality by menopausal status

Fig. 2.
We observed a 93% increase in overall age-adjusted breast cancer incidence through the period from 1995 to 2017 (incidence rate ratio 1.93, 95% CI 1.42–2.62) (Fig. 1).

Pre-diagnostic lifestyle factors: overall mortality and breast cancer-specific mortality
Among all breast cancer cases combined, we observed a 96% increased overall mortality risk for those breast cancer cases with three to five unfavorable lifestyle factors versus no unfavorable lifestyle factors (HR 1.96, 95% CI 1.01–3.80) (Table 4, Fig. 2).
